title: Help & Documentation
subtitle: Learn how to use WSL UI

gettingStarted.title: Getting Started
gettingStarted.whatIsWslUiText: WSL UI is a desktop application for managing Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) distributions. It provides a graphical interface for common WSL operations like starting, stopping, creating, and configuring Linux distributions.
gettingStarted.mainDashboardText: The main view shows all your installed WSL distributions as cards. Each card displays the distribution name, status (online/offline), disk usage, and quick action buttons.
gettingStarted.quickActionsText: Click the menu button (three dots) on any distribution card to access quick actions like opening a terminal, file explorer, IDE, or managing the distribution.

distroManagement.title: Distribution Management
distroManagement.setAsDefaultText: Set a distribution as default to use it when running WSL commands without specifying a distribution name.
distroManagement.resourceMonitoringText: Running distributions show real-time CPU and memory usage. Disk size is displayed for all distributions.

advancedOps.title: Advanced Operations
advancedOps.renameText: Change a distribution's name. You can also update the Windows Terminal profile and Start Menu shortcut. Requires the distribution to be stopped.
advancedOps.moveText: Relocate a distribution to a different drive or folder. Useful for managing disk space. Requires WSL to be fully shut down.
advancedOps.resizeDiskText: Expand the virtual disk size for distributions that need more space. Only expansion is supported (not shrinking). Requires WSL shutdown.
advancedOps.setWslVersionText: Convert between WSL 1 and WSL 2. WSL 2 offers better performance with a full Linux kernel. Conversion may take several minutes.
advancedOps.sparseModeText: Enable automatic disk space reclamation. The virtual disk will shrink as you delete files inside the distribution.
advancedOps.compactDiskText: One-click optimization to reclaim unused space from a distribution's virtual disk. Automatically runs fstrim, shuts down WSL, and compacts the VHDX file. Requires administrator privileges and takes 1-2 minutes.

creatingDistros.title: Creating Distributions
creatingDistros.quickInstallText: One-click installation of official distributions like Ubuntu, Debian, and openSUSE.
creatingDistros.containerImagesText: Create distributions from Docker or Podman container images. Supports Docker Hub and other registries.
creatingDistros.directDownloadText: Download rootfs archives from configurable URLs. Includes Alpine, NixOS, Void Linux, and more.
creatingDistros.communityCatalogText: Browse hundreds of distributions from the Linux Containers image server.

backupRestore.title: Backup & Restore
backupRestore.exportText: Save a distribution to a .tar archive file for backup or migration. You can restore it later or on another machine.
backupRestore.importText: Restore a distribution from a .tar archive. Choose a name and installation location for the imported distribution.
backupRestore.cloneText: Create a copy of an existing distribution with a new name. Useful for testing or creating variants.

customActions.title: Custom Actions
customActions.whatAreText: Custom actions are user-defined shell commands that appear in the quick actions menu. Create actions for common tasks like system updates, backups, or development setup.
customActions.variablesText: Use variables in your commands that get replaced at runtime:
customActions.targetingText: Actions can target all distributions, specific distributions by name, or distributions matching a regex pattern.

theming.title: Themes & Appearance
theming.builtinThemesText: Choose from 17 professionally designed themes including dark, light, and middle-ground options. Popular themes include Obsidian, Dracula, Nord, and Solarized.
theming.accessibilityThemesText: Two high contrast themes are available for users with low vision: High Contrast (dark) and High Contrast Light.
theming.customThemeText: Create your own theme with full control over 29 color variables including backgrounds, text, borders, accents, and more.

keyboardShortcuts.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
keyboardShortcuts.accessibilityText: WSL UI supports screen readers, keyboard navigation, and respects system preferences for reduced motion.

settingsOverview.title: Settings Overview
settingsOverview.terminal: Terminal: Configure Windows Terminal, custom terminal apps, or command prompt
settingsOverview.ide: IDE: Set up VS Code, Cursor, or custom IDE integration
settingsOverview.wslGlobal: WSL Global: Configure memory, CPU, swap, networking mode, and WSLg
settingsOverview.perDistro: Per-Distribution: Automount options, network settings, systemd, and boot commands
settingsOverview.polling: Polling: Adjust auto-refresh intervals for status and resources
settingsOverview.timeouts: Timeouts: Configure operation timeouts for slow systems
settingsOverview.executables: Executable Paths: Override default paths for WSL, PowerShell, and other tools

integrations.title: Integrations
integrations.terminalText: Open distributions in Windows Terminal, Command Prompt, or any custom terminal application. Configure your preferred terminal in Settings.
integrations.ideText: Open distributions directly in VS Code or other IDEs. The distribution's root folder opens in your editor.
integrations.fileExplorerText: Browse distribution files in Windows Explorer using the \\wsl$ network path.
integrations.systemTrayText: Minimize to system tray for quick access. Configure close behavior in Settings.

troubleshooting.title: Troubleshooting
troubleshooting.wslNotDetectedText: Ensure WSL is installed and enabled. Run wsl --status in PowerShell to check. You may need to enable the Windows features for WSL.
troubleshooting.operationsTimeoutText: If operations frequently timeout, increase the timeout values in Settings > Timeouts. The app uses exponential backoff to reduce load during issues.
troubleshooting.distroWontStartText: Try restarting WSL with wsl --shutdown, then start the distribution again.
